article_text:
Who let the inmates out?

As the Republican Party continues to eat itself, pundits are running amok with metaphors, gastronomic and otherwise, to explain what in the Potomac is going on.

article_metadata.description: The Republican establishment has lit “a wildfire … that has now consumed them,” Mark Jones, a political science professor at Rice University, told Houston Chronicle staff writer Mike Ward.  The GOP is “committing suicide on national television,” tweeted Jamie Johnson, a former aide to Rick Perry’s presidential campaign, during last week’s Republican debate.  A year earlier, a riot in the asylum erupted in opposition to the economic policies of President Barack Obama, the color of his skin or some combination thereof.  GOP presidential front-runner Donald Trump, for instance, capitalized on the movement’s racist and xenophobic dimensions, echoing the right-wing conspiracy theory that Obama was born in Kenya.  In 2013, defunding Obamacare was the purpose of his absurd, maddening quest that shut down the government, seriously irritating Senate leaders in the process.  [...] in an ironic twist, Republican leaders, including some in the Senate, are beginning to consider presidential candidate Cruz their last, best hope to restore sanity.  An unstable person, for instance, was just elected chairman of the Travis County Republican Party.  [...] the Republican establishment here remains reluctant to act stable.
article_metadata.author.name: By Brian Chasnoff, Staff Writer
